articles.headline: The Ripples of Punishing One Bank
articles.snippet: It has taken four months and complex negotiations to transfer the money, contained in accounts frozen at the bank.
articles.abstract: It has taken four months and complex negotiations to transfer the money, contained in accounts frozen at the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the United States blacklisted a tiny bank in Macao for its dealings with North Korea nearly two years ago, the goal was to isolate the bank from the world’s financial system and squeeze the government in Pyongyang.

articles.headline: Engaging at Any Speed? Commercials Put to Test
articles.snippet: In new experiments for NBC, people are observed as they watch commercials in fast-forward mode.
articles.abstract: In new experiments for NBC, people are observed as they watch commercials in fast-forward mode.
articles.lead_paragraph: In new experiments for NBC, people are hooked up to sensors as they watch television, and researchers observe changes in their heart rate, palm sweat, eye movement and breathing patterns.

articles.headline: Short on Money, McCain Campaign Dismisses Dozens
articles.snippet: The campaign of Senator John McCain acknowledged that it was in crisis after it raised just $11.2 million in the last three months.
articles.abstract: The campaign of Senator John McCain acknowledged that it was in crisis after it raised just $11.2 million in the last three months.
articles.lead_paragraph: The presidential campaign of Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who once seemed poised to be his party’s nominee in 2008, acknowledged yesterday that it was in a political and financial crisis as a drop in fund-raising forced it to dismiss dozens of workers and aides and retool its strategy on where to compete.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: U.S. Says Iran Helped Iraqis Kill Five G.I.’s
articles.snippet: A charge by a U.S. military spokesman was the most specific allegation of Iranian involvement in an attack that killed American troops.
articles.abstract: A charge by a U.S. military spokesman was the most specific allegation of Iranian involvement in an attack that killed American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, July 2 — Agents of Iran helped plan a January raid in Shiite holy city of Karbala in Iraq in which five American soldiers were killed by Islamic militants, an American military spokesman said Monday. The charge was the most specific allegation of Iranian involvement in an attack that killed American troops, at a time of rising tensions with Iran over its role in Iraq and its nuclear program.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: New Scheme Preys on Desperate Homeowners
articles.snippet: The schemes take various forms and often involve promises to distressed homeowners of cash upfront.
articles.abstract: The schemes take various forms and often involve promises to distressed homeowners of cash upfront.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the housing market in decline, financial predators are finding yet another way to take advantage of people who fall behind on their payments.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Companies Giving Green an Office
articles.snippet: Corporations are adding a new title to the executive suite — chief sustainability officer — not just an environmental watchdog, but someone to oversee the effort to go green.
articles.abstract: Corporations are adding a new title to the executive suite — chief sustainability officer — not just an environmental watchdog, but someone to oversee the effort to go green.
articles.lead_paragraph: The corporate roster of “chiefs” used to be pretty short: chief executive, chief financial officer and, maybe, chief operating officer. Then came the chief marketing and technology officers.

articles.headline: A Slippery, Writhing Trade Dispute
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration says Xulong and other Chinese companies will be restricted from selling certain types of seafood in the United States.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration says Xulong and other Chinese companies will be restricted from selling certain types of seafood in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAISHAN, China, June 30 — At the Xulong eel factory here, a team of workers slice eels, lop off their heads and push them through a huge assembly line that will cook and package them for millions of customers around the world.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Continue Public Path
articles.snippet: Och-Ziff Capital Management, a $26.8 billion hedge fund, filed for a $2 billion initial public offering on Monday.
articles.abstract: Och-Ziff Capital Management, a $26.8 billion hedge fund, filed for a $2 billion initial public offering on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Increasingly skeptical investors and lawmakers are apparently not enough to deter yet another hedge fund giant from going public.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Medical Workers Emerge as Focus in British Inquiry
articles.snippet: Police investigating the failed car bombings in London and Glasgow focused on suspects in the medical profession, including a doctor from Jordan and another from Iraq.
articles.abstract: Police investigating the failed car bombings in London and Glasgow focused on suspects in the medical profession, including a doctor from Jordan and another from Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Tuesday, July 3 — British police officials investigating the failed car bombings in London and Glasgow focused Monday on suspects in the medical profession, including a doctor from Jordan, another from Iraq, and medical workers or students. As many as five of the seven people arrested so far in Britain appear to have such links.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Raymond Bonner
